summary: shigellosis is caused by four species, S. dysenteriae, S. flexneri, S. boydii, and S. sonnei. a total of 47 serotypes of Shigella have been recognized. the vaccine effectiveness depends on the distribution patterns of local species and serotypes. recent reports have indicated that S. flexneri 2a is the most frequently isolated Shigella organism in China [15,16]. the time period of these studies is short, and surveillance is performed only in less-developed areas of China. only one Shigella isolate per patient per diarrheal episode was included in the analysis. p 0.05 was considered statistically significant. only one Shigella isolate per patient per diarrheal episode was included in the analysis. a total of 5999 Shigella isolates were collected from 372 inpatients. a final total of 5987 isolates were further analyzed in this study. subgroup trends A statistically significant decreasing trend in S. flexneri and an increasing trend in S. sonnei were observed by chi-square analysis. between 1994 and 2005, Shigella isolation rates were largely driven by S. flexneri. in 2006, S. sonnei became the dominant subgroup. in 2009, the lowest percentage of isolated S. flexneri (6%) was recorded. infections in the largest infectious hospital in Beijing over a period of 17 years (1994 to 2010) the changing trend of Shigella in Beijing over time was determined in this work. the results will be useful in providing information that can be used to implement control strategies or predict the efficacy of vaccines for the prevention of shigellosis. the 2006 data were compared with that of another similar report based on a study in Henan Province, China, in 2006 [18]. the highest temperature in Beijing was recorded in August, while that in Zhengzhou, Henan Province, was recorded in July. the high temperatures appear to more related to the seasonality of the Shigella infection than to the amount of rainfall. the change across 17 years in dominant Shigella species from S. flexneri to S. sonnei was uncovered. results would be important in the treatment and prevention of shigellosis.
